field.name: summary
field.value: Calling an Action that does not exist does not result in a 404

field.name: description
field.value:
...it results in an exception stating that the view for that action cannot be found.
Just call a non-existant action on any existing controller. E.g. /controller/garbage.rails. This will attempt to find a view for the action 'garbage' which does not exist.
This is caused by a slightly overzealous attempt to save the situation when an action cannot be found. In DefaultActionSelector the DefaultAction for the controller is returned even in cases where a 404 should be the result. This should only happen if the Action name is null or empty (i.e. a request for /controller/).
The Controller class does the right thing if it gets back null from the DefaultActionSelector. It will throw an exception with a 404 status code it it gets null. This isn't happening now because of the errant behavior in DefaultActionSelector.

comment.author: jamescurran
comment.text:
This is not correct. If I have a [DefaultAction] indicated on my controller, then /controller/garbage.rails SHOULD use that action.
The problem may be that the DefaultAction is being wrongly set, that would be a different problem.
Also, your patch file tries to replace every line in the file, even though only about 4 lines changed. That would suggest that your whitespace (use tabs) or line ending setting is wrong.

comment.author: jsimons
comment.text: The DefaultActionAttribute attribute provides a way to associate a default action method that will be called if a matching action method can not be found on the controller. See http://www.castleproject.org/monorail/documentation/v20/usersguide/controllerbasics.html#DefaultAction
